moves.1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4: A common opening shape for Sicillian with pawns exchanged on d4.
moves.4... Nc6 5. Nc3 Nf6 6. Be3 a6: with Be3 White develops and protects the d4 Knight. Black defends b5 square.
moves.7. Be2 e5: Black choses a Najdorf variation, kicking the d4 Knight.
moves.8. Nf3 Be7 9. O-O Bg4: Black develops pieces actively, hoping to gain compensation for White lost time.
moves.10. Nxe5: White initiates a Combination, attacking c3 and the g4 square twice.
moves.10... Bxe2 11. Nxc6: White has to keep going with this plan,  11.Qxe2 Nxe5 and White sacifice will be in vain.
moves.11... Bxd1 12. Nxd8 Bxc2: Material may be even, but the game is loosening up.
moves.13. Nxb7 Bxe4: That's the position after the end of the capturing.
moves.14. Na5 d5: White needs to be aware of the Knights on the same diagonal, with a DSB lurking.  Black chooses to keep the Bishop up the board.  Also the d-pawn is vunerable and Black needs to get something for it.
moves.15. f3 Bd3 16. Rfd1 Bc4 17. b3 Bb4: White may have been in a better position with NxBc4
moves.18. bxc4 Bxc3 19. Bb6 Bxa1 20. Re1+: White at least tries to get a centralised King out of the loss of Exchange
moves.20... Kd7 21. Rxa1 dxc4 22. Nxc4 Rac8: Black is aware that there are forking opportunities for a roaming Knight.  It doesn't help Black that a King, two Rooks and some pawns will be close together. Black is concious of where to place the rooks in relation to each other and the King.
moves.23. Ne5+ Ke6 24. Re1 Rhe8: With a discovered check coming Black wanted to threaten immediately after the King moved. An unprotected d6 would be perfect for a White Knight.
moves.25. Ng6+ Kd7 26. Rxe8: Maybe with two threatened pieces he had to exchange
moves.27... Rb8 28. Bd4: Another error, White was trying to protect the a-pawn by protecting the a1 and b2 squares but has put his unprotected  B and Knight on same rank.
moves.28... Rb4 29. Bxf6 gxf6: Some debate about qualities of the Bishor and Knight in Endgame.  For Black,they didn't want to lose a pawn in the Exchange, however White cleverly put paid to that schemme with some quality fork moves, showing the advantages of a Knight in a small area.  The disadvantages came later in try to defend the whole board.
moves.30. Nd5 Rb1+ 31. Kf2 Rb2+ 32. Kg3 Rxa2: Black clears the way for his a-pawn, Whit King is brought into the action.
moves.33. Nxf6+ Ke6 34. Nxh7: Whites shows what the Knight can do.
moves.34... a5 35. h4: because Black has two separate pawn groups,White
moves.35... a4: Black maybe getting greedy, 35.Kf5 might put a hole in Whites progress.
moves.36. Ng5+ Kf6 37. Ne4+ Kg6 38. Nc3 Ra1 39: Black is happy, maybe White could have delayed a capture and tried to sneak some of his pawns further up the board.
moves.40. Kh3 f5: Black wanting to whittle down White's defence.
moves.41. g3 f4 42. g4: White has only two active pawns and running out of moves.
